Octane AI

Octane AI Build your audience on Facebook Messenger.
Role

Lead Designer

Art Director

Jackie Cruickshank

Agency

West Agile Labs

Year

Winter 2016

View Live
Allow anyone with no knowledge of chatbots, to build a chatbot in only a few minutes.

Over 1 billion people use Facebook messenger every month. That's more than Snapchat, Instagram, and Twitter combined. At the moment, there's no sign of it slowing down. With publishers and content creators amassing fan bases as large as 34m+ followers like Aerosmith, building chatbots provides an opportunity to engage your audience on a mass scale like never before.

At the beginning of fall 2016, Matt Schilitcht, Ben Parr, and Leif K-Brooks saw this huge market opportunity to design and build a technology to allow anyone, with or without a chatbot. After an exhaustive search, they partnered with West Agile Labs to help build out their vision of a more automated and connected messaging platform.

I oversaw the design efforts for simplifying the complex nature of chatbots. Branding and art direction was driven by Jackie Cruickshank while I lead product and interaction design with help from Danielle Hadley. With a focus on iterative and rapid prototyping, we were able to design a fully responsive chatbot management platform in under 2 months. Octane AI had a successful private launch 2 months later with industry leading publishers joining the platform and a series A raise.

Track Your Bot

After the chatbot has been created, a user can monitor their bot from a high-level or individual plugin level. This allows for users to monitor the engagement level of their content within Facebook Messenger, previously only available through Newsfeed. From here, a user can quickly update or push new content through the plugins that have alreayd been created.

Content Integrations & Plugin Health

We designed a solution that other developers can build and add integrations to the Octane AI ecosystem. This enabled chatbot managers to elevate their messenger bot to pull in content from a variety of sources, such as Spotify and Soundcloud.

Furthermore, we created an analytics template that scale to any native Octanei AI extension or integration from the developer ecosystem.

Custom Responses

While we designed the app to make it as easy as possible for users to create responses to common messages, there's always the chance that people will be sending messages to a chatbot that it doesn't understand. We designed and created 'train your both' to quickly view and create responses to every unknown message. They can either have a singular mass response such as, "I didn't get that." Alternatively, they also have the option to build a randomized list of responses to each individual unknown message, truly allowing the users character to appear in their chatbot.

Results

Octane AI had a successful beta launch and quickly raised a series A round. However, some of their beta users include: 50 Cent, Aerosmith, Kiss, 30 Seconds to Mars, SPiN and Magic Mike Live. Their current focus is to market to content producers and publishers to manage their high volume of fans. The successful beta launch of their MVP allowed Octane AI to raise a significant amount of capital to slowly start building out their team. They currently have a team of 10 designing out building the product further. Excited to see where this goes in the future.

100+ Million fans interacting with Octane AI Chatbots
3:00 Average time to set up a chatbot
Industry Responses

“Their business is like web design platforms Wix or Weebly, but for chatbots. It’s a paint-by-numbers for bot creation that’s so easy, I could do it. (I did it! I programmed the Katie Roof bot to respond with “raise the roof” as my greeting. Sorry but not sorry).”

Katie Roof — TechCrunch

“Octane AI is a platform that enables businesses to set up powerful chatbots on Facebook Messenger in just a few minutes.”

Tech.Co

“Octane keeps that promise of five minutes or less”

VentureBeat

“I built a chatbot. It can only do a handful of things, and it’s even dumber than the average chatbot. But it works, and I can talk to it through Facebook Messenger. More importantly, I’m not a coder.”

Ellen Huet — Bloomberg
